title: 114_hr4943
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tribal Tax and Investment Reform Act of 2016". The findings are also included in the Act. The Congress recognizes the unique relationship between the United States and Indian tribes, acknowledging their authority to provide governmental programs and services, develop economies, and maintain infrastructure on reservation lands. Federal laws and treaties affirm the sovereignty of tribal governments, allowing them to tax, issue bonds, and receive tax exemptions. Tax parity for tribal governments aligns with their recognized sovereignty and addresses historic capital access challenges. Indian tribes face historic disadvantages in accessing capital for infrastructure and governance, leading to unfair tax treatment and unequal enforcement. Congress asserts its authority to regulate commerce with tribes to promote self-governance and strengthen the government-to-government relationship. Indian tribes are treated as states with respect to bond issuance. Indian tribal governments are treated as states for certain purposes related to tax-exempt bonds. The Secretary of the Treasury establishes a national bond volume cap for Indian tribal governments based on population estimates and allocates it among tribes seeking an allocation. The national bond volume cap for Indian tribal governments is adjusted annually based on the cost of living provision. Essential governmental function requirements are repealed, and the effective date for these changes varies depending on the subsection. SEC. 4. Treatment of pension and employee benefit plans maintained by tribal governments. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include expanding the definition of qualified public safety employee to include Indian tribes and updating the definition of governmental plan to encompass plans established by Indian tribal governments or entities. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include Indian tribal governments and entities in the definition of qualified public safety employee and governmental plan. This encompasses plans established by Indian tribal governments or entities. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include Indian tribal governments and entities in the definition of qualified public safety employee and governmental plan. Plans established by Indian tribal governments or entities are grandfathered under certain deferred compensation plans. Amendments are made to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 regarding governmental plans. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 include expanding the definition of "governmental plan" to include plans established by Indian tribal governments or entities. This encompasses plans for employees of Indian tribal governments, subdivisions, agencies, instrumentalities, or entities wholly owned or controlled by them. Additionally, a domestic relations order under the Act now includes tribal entities. Conforming amendments are also made to certain sections of the Act. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 now include tribal entities in the definition of "governmental plan." This encompasses plans for employees of Indian tribal governments, subdivisions, agencies, instrumentalities, or entities wholly owned or controlled by them. Conforming amendments are made to certain sections of the Act to include tribal entities in domestic relations orders. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 has been amended to include tribal entities in the definition of "governmental plan." This applies to plans for employees of Indian tribal governments, subdivisions, agencies, instrumentalities, or entities wholly owned or controlled by them. Amendments made to certain sections of the Act now include tribal entities in domestic relations orders. The effective date for these amendments is for years beginning after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. Tribal foundations and charities treated like charities funded and controlled by governmental funders and sponsors. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include recognizing Indian tribal governments and related entities as governmental units for tax purposes. This applies to supporting organizations and is effective for taxable years after the enactment of the Act. Improving tribal child support enforcement agencies by granting equal access to federal parent locator service and tax refund offsets. Granting equal access to federal parent locator service and tax refund offsets for Indian tribes and tribal organizations eligible for grants under specific sections of the Social Security Act. Eligible Indian tribes and tribal organizations can receive grants under specific sections of the Social Security Act, with provisions similar to those for states with approved plans. Additionally, the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include Indian tribes and tribal organizations in references to states for certain purposes. SEC. 7 amends the Internal Revenue Code to include Indian tribal governments in determining special needs for the adoption credit. Effective for taxable years after enactment.
